user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of reply_with_area2_pages:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
reply_with_area2_pages (struct MHD_Connection *c,
                        const char *url)
{

  if (0 == strcmp (url, SEC_AREA2_URL ""))
  {
    static const char page_content[] =
      "<html><head><title>Very restricted secret page</title></head>" \
      "<body>Welcome to the super restricted area</body></html>";
    static const size_t page_content_len =
      (sizeof(page_content) / sizeof(char)) - 1;
    struct MHD_Response *resp;
    enum MHD_Result ret;

    resp = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (page_content_len,
                                                   page_content);
    if (NULL == resp)
      return MHD_NO;

    /* Ignore possible error when adding the header as the reply will work even
       without this header. */
    (void) MHD_add_response_header (resp, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_TYPE,
                                    "text/html");

    ret = MHD_queue_response (c, MHD_HTTP_OK, resp);
    MHD_destroy_response (resp);
    return ret;
  }
  /* If needed: add handlers for other URLs in this area */
#if 0 /* Disabled code */
  if (0 == strcmp (url, SEC_AREA2_URL "other_path/other_page"))
  {
    /* Add page creation/processing code */
  }
#endif /* Disabled code */

  /* The requested URL is unknown */
  return reply_with_page_not_found (c);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. The function parameters are: 'struct MHD_Connection *c' and 'const char *url'. There are no assignments, increments/decrements, or any other operations that modify these parameter variables themselves (no statements like c = ..., url = ..., ++url, url += n, or taking their address and writing through that). The code only: - reads 'url' (passed to strcmp) which does not modify the pointer or the pointed-to data (strcmp takes const char *). - passes 'c' to functions (MHD_queue_response, reply_with_page_not_found), which may modify the object pointed to (allowed by the rule) but do not modify the parameter variable inside this function. - uses a disabled (#if 0) block that is not compiled. There are also no casts removing const, nor any usage that would make the pointer itself an lvalue for modification. Therefore no fragments in this function violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
